comments.content:
Confirm, it is set-casmailbox the firts.
On premises only EAC and PowerShell are supported in the Client Access Rule

discussion.content: New-ClientAccessRule is the right answer for both of them, as per Microsoft this command is available in on-premises Exchange and in the cloud-based service.

the first one set-casmailbox -owaenabled $false
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/set-casmailbox?view=exchange-ps


the second one new-clientaccessrule -AnyOfProtocols outlookwebapp -actions -scope
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/set-clientaccessrule?view=exchange-ps

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your company has a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 hybrid deployment.
Users in the company's accounting department have on-premises mailboxes. Users in the company's sales department have mailboxes in Exchange Online.
You need to configure Outlook on the web to meet the following requirements:
✑ The accounting department users must be prevented from using Outlook on the web.
✑ The sales department users must be prevented from using Outlook on the web from the Internet.
✑ The accounting and sales department users must be able to use Outlook Anywhere and Exchange ActiveSync.
Which cmdlet should you run for the users in each department? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: The second one - Paris admins should be able to use EAC to create the new mailboxes - should be "yes", right?

C is answer, you cannot purge from database its already deleted.

The Remove-MailboxDatabase cmdlet removes only the database object from Active Directory. It doesn't remove the physical database files. You must remove the database files manually after you run the Remove-MailboxDatabase cmdlet.
Database DB01 is already removed from AD, so the only thing you have to do, to reclaim disk space, is to delete the files (remove-item). I believe the correct answer is A.
The correct answer is C. The question asks to reclaim disk space, not to purge the mailboxes from DB

comments.content: D is the correct answer, when you move the mailboxes from DB01 to DB02, they go into soft deleted state in DB01, then when Remove-StoreMailbox is run DB01 is purged and reclaims available space.
C is correct, database is already deleted so all other options don't make any sense.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains multiple servers. The Exchange organization contains a server named EX01. EX01 contains a mailbox database that uses 200 GB of disk space.
You run the following commands on EX01.
//IMG//

You need to reclaim the available disk space on EX01.

choices.B: From a command prompt, run the eseutil.exe /R EX01 command.
choices.A: From Exchange Management Shell, run the Remove-MigrationBatch cmdlet and specify the Force parameter.
choices.D: From Exchange Management Shell, run the Remove-StoreMailbox cmdlet.
choices.C: From Exchange Management Shell, run the Remove-Item cmdlet and specify the Path parameter.

choices.D: On each Mailbox server, run the Set-OwaVirtualDirectory cmdlet and specify the ""ExternalURLs $null parameter.
choices.C: On the Edge Transport server, run the Set-OwaVirtualDirectory cmdlet and specify the ""AllowOfflineOn NoComputers parameter.
choices.A: Run the Set-OWMailboxPolicy cmdlet and specify the ""ExplicitLogonEnabled $true parameter
choices.B: Run the Set-OWMailboxPolicy cmdlet and specify the ""AllowOfflineOn NoComputers parameter

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization that contains four Mailbox servers and one Edge Transport server. The organization supports hundreds of remote users.
You need to block offline access to Outlook on the web for all the users.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
For me :
The correct answer "B. Run the Set-OWMailboxPolicy cmdlet and specify the ""AllowOfflineOn NoComputers parameter"

The AllowOfflineOn parameter is available on both Set-OWAMailboxPolicy & Set-OWAVirtualDirectory, however the question specifies "all the users". Using Set-OWAVirtualDirectoy on the Edge server would only affect remote users vs using the Set-OWAMailboxPolicy which can modify the "Default" Outlook Web App Policy affecting all users.
i think the correct answer is C but the point is that i don't think that the edge server has IIS where we can run Exchange Cmdlets ?

Correct answer is C
Use Set-OWAMailboxPolicy cmdlet if you want to modify an existing OWA mailbox policy. To apply OWA mailbox policy to a particular mailbox, you must use Set-CasMailbox
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/apply-or-remove-outlook-web-app-mailbox-policy-exchange-2013-help
Also, best not to run Exchange on a DC

It is correct.
All servers within a DAG must be running the same version of Exchange. For example, you can't mix Exchange 2013 servers and Exchange 2016 servers in the same DAG.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/high-availability/database-availability-groups/database-availability-groups?view=exchserver-2019

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory forest. The forest contains two domains named litware.com and exchange.litware.com and a Microsoft Exchange
Server 2019 organization.
The relevant servers are configured as shown in the following table.
//IMG//

EX01 and EX02 have Exchange Server 2019 installed and are in a database availability group (DAG) named DAG01.
You need to add in additional server to DAG01.
Which server should you add?
